summary: The project is well-structured and should build and run successfully. All dependencies are properly configured, code follows good practices, and entry point is correctly defined.

details.description: pyproject.toml file found with valid project configuration
Requires Python >=3.12, which is appropriate for pygame and numpy dependencies
pygame>=2.6.1 and numpy>=2.0.0 are correctly specified. Both are widely available and compatible.
.venv directory exists with pygame and numpy already installed
uv.lock file exists for reproducible builds
main.py exists with proper if __name__ == '__main__' guard
All imports (pygame, sys, local modules) are correctly structured
main.py imports Game from game.py which exists. All module imports are resolvable.
Proper pygame.init() call before Game() instantiation. Clean exit with pygame.quit() and sys.exit()
All Python files have valid syntax with no parsing errors
Code is well-organized into modules: main.py, config.py, entity.py, game.py, level.py
All classes (Player, Ghost, Key, Door, Game, Level) are properly defined with __init__ methods
config.py defines all constants used throughout the codebase. Constants match appinfo.json specifications.
pygame is imported and used correctly across all modules
numpy is listed in dependencies but not currently used in code - this is acceptable for future use
sys and math are correctly imported from Python standard library
No circular dependency detected. Import chain: main -> game -> entity, config, level -> config
Game.run() implements proper game loop with event handling, update, and render phases
Collision detection uses pygame.Rect.colliderect() which is the correct pygame API
Event handling properly checks QUIT, KEYDOWN events for R (reset) and ESCAPE (quit)
Uses clock.tick(FPS) to maintain 60 FPS as specified in requirements
Uses 800x600 resolution matching appinfo.json requirements
Color is set twice for facing_right=False case. This is a minor code issue but won't affect runtime.
pygame.quit() is called in Game.run() but also in main.py, resulting in double cleanup. This is harmless but redundant.
numpy is listed as a dependency but not used in current code. May be intended for future features.
uv sync command is appropriate and will work with existing pyproject.toml and uv.lock
uv run python main.py will execute the entry point correctly
Python 3.12+, pygame, numpy, 800x600 resolution, 60 FPS - all match code implementation
All 5 mechanics (shifting walls, boo-logic enemies, invisible platforms, win/lose conditions) are implemented

recommendations: The code is production-ready and should run without issues.
Minor code cleanup could address the redundant color assignment in entity.py lines 86-88.
Consider removing sys.exit() from Game.run() since main.py already handles cleanup, or keep it for safety.
